Bottle in a trade a while back. Pour is a glorious cloudy gold with a rocky white head. Aroma is bursting with orange, light barn funk, faint saison spice, light acidic notes, and light herbal notes.  Flavor is tart and citrusy up front with notes of lemon peel and orange. Then spicy saison notes kick in with a juicy and spicy finish. Just a great beer. Another hit from this brewery.

Bottle poured a pale hazy yellow with a three finger pillow of a head.  Beautiful retention, and beer overall.

Flavor and nose was saison yeast, honey, slight tartness with one crack of fresh pepper.  Incredible balance between tart and sweetness.  Hard to believe this is a shelf beer

This poured a somewhat hazy yellow color with a white head.  Aroma was of light citrusy hops, some light spices and peppery notes, brett, and lemon peel.  Flavor was more tart than expecting, pushing towards almost a sour ale, but still enough spice and yeast components to show it is a saison.  Crackery, yeast, and lemons mainly.
Bottle. Golden pour, white head. Nose is light honey, apricot, peaches. Taste is stone fruit, honey, well water, fresh bread. Very dry, light bodied.

Aroma: lots of citrus with lemon right up front, some light malts and a touch of honey, fresh cut hay, some weizen-like phenolics, light Brett funk.
Appearance: light straw yellow color with a slight haze, billowing white head with excellent retention and nice lacing.
Taste: really nice lemon notes and some pleasant acidity, Brett character comes across as some light funk with leather, leaves, and spiciness.  Light malts with some yeast and dough, also some honey and herbal notes.  Light and refreshing, with a dry finish.
Palate: fairly light body, high carbonation, quite spritzy.
Overall: A really nice saison - refreshing and drinkable.

Bouteille de 750ml. merci Patrick. Bière jaune trouble très effervescente. Au nez cette bière rappelle les bières belges de fermentations spontanées tant la levure saison donne un côté sauvage. Les effluves de fleurs blanches et de miel nous invitent à déguster ce nectar de choix. En bouche la bière est rafraichissante, citronnée avec une finale sur la levure saison. Lapport de gaz carbonique lui confère un côté rafraichissant.

Thanks to Time4lunch for sending me some of that HF goodness. Bottle opened at Hunah day 2013. This is probably my favorite saison Ive ever had. Aroma is light honey and wildflower, hops, some yeast and funk, lemony citrus and herbal qualities. Complex. Body is hazy yellow with a fizzy white head. Flavors match up with honey in the background, some herbal and flowery notes under yeast, a touch of spice, and some hops. Very nice.

Jordan, you are the man. This my first Hill Farmstead beer and already I understand what the hype is all about. The body is damn-near perfect; a clean yellow body with a thick, seafoam head. Aromas reveal bready esters with light herbs and honey among hops and... well water. The taste is full of these bready flavors with a buttery, malty, whole-grain and sweet basil balance that is both spicy and light at the same time. I could drink this forever.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2015 Une bouteille de 75 cl.  Une robe voilée et jaune surmontée par une tête blanche indesctructible.  Une dentelle sur la paroi.  Un nez assez vibrant de houblons, de fleurs et dherbes de la campagne.  Une contribution docile des malts pâles.  Des parfums citronnés dans cette démonstration qui me rappelle, les yeux fermés, une approche lambic.  Sur les papilles, un travail énorme des houblons.  Des fleurs qui mordent des herbes.  Des notes citronnées fouettées par une levure: un caractère acidulé qui ne transporte que de la fraîcheur.  En bouche, un corps léger avec un pétillement généreux et une texture presque huileuse.  Une finale très sèche, poivrée, astringente et fruitée.  //Plusieurs autres bouteilles au fil des saisons.  Anna ma déjà beaucoup plus mais présentement elle me lasse un peu.  Ceci dit, elle demeure une bonne bière à prix raisonnable.

big thanks to whatsarezaf for this one. the pour is a hazy yellow a little cloudy on some of the other glasses at the tasting mine was a nice clean yellow. stong lemon and honey notes very floral taste was remarkable dry and crisp light fruit notes this is off memory from last night this was a super beer

A: Dirty yellow, very hazy as expected since I open this right after getting delivered. S: Very nice lemon smell, some tropical fruits, honey, yeast funk, and old wood. T: A very nice lime taste to it, with lemon tartness, light honey and sugar to keep this one together, light spice with some lime juice  and yeast funk towards the end. M: Light and creamy with high carbonation, very crispy. O: I really like this one.

Growler. Pours a cloudy yellow with small white head that diminishes quickly to nothing. The aroma is funk and sour fruit.  Medium mouthfeel with a refreshing sweet hop and fruit with light dry finish. Easy to drink a very good saison from HF.

Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip.  From notes.

Anna has a cloudy, bright golden color with a huge white head.  As I expect from a well-made saison, the cap fades to a more modest size while leaving sticky sheets of lace down the side of my glass.

The aroma is sticky sweet, with notes of pale malt, honey, and crackers.  There are pear and lemon zest esters as well, adding a subtle depth of character to the smell.

Each sip is smooth, starting out with a dry maltiness that I expect out of a saison.  The notes of pear, honey, lemon zest, and general spice weave into each other, creating a nice balance between the light malts, sweetness, and tinge of tartness.  Some more herbal notes come in toward the end of the sip, and the last flavor on my tongue is the spicy yeast.

There is quite a dry mouthfeel throughout, with vibrant and energetic carbonation helping to aid with the lightness of the feel and the aromatics.  Crisp.

After a certain point I should just get the message that this is not my style and stop reviewing saisons.  Clearly this is a well made beer, but I did not really connect with it.

750, capped, at Mikkeller. To say this beer is highly carbonated would be to grossly underestimate the ambitions of the carbon dioxide therein. Popping the cap was a big fat jailbreak for this beer. All three bartenders got at least a little tiny bit splashed. Shot everywhere. Big white geyser. Striking. Hazy medium gold in the glass, fluffy eggy head settles quickly to not much, as expected, and the carb was a little on the light side, as expected--too much was lost. Not to the great detriment of the beer by any means, but softened and mellowed it a little overmuch. Big honey nose, showing a little bit of minty herbaceousness and caramel as well, along with some sweet floral notes. That yeast and that honey sugar been makin bebbehs in the bottleses. Creamy medium body, understated carb. Honey, toasty malt, floral bits, and grassiness on the mid palate, with a minty, honeyed finish.

A beautiful beer. This one is golden colored with a tornado funnel of effervescence rushing to the surface. The head is pure white and just over an inch thick. Excellent retention with ample lacing left behind.

The aroma offers yeast, grass, grand floral notes, lemon, light spice, subtle farm funk.

A touch of honey. Mildly sweet with a healthy floral presence throughout. Every aspect of the beer is so delicate and balanced. Just beautiful. Bready malts with hints of spice. Pronounced floral bitterness. Finishes dry.

Its always a treat to enjoy anything by Hill Farmstead. I thought this was outstanding.

Big time lemon yeasty scent, taste is similar with a little spicy/pepperiness, great lemon finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

January 20, 2013 - bottle via trade with Matt.  Cloudy yellow pour with huge head that lasted.  Honey, yeast, and malt in aroma and taste.  Finish had a slight but yet somewhat sweet bitterness.  These guys just know how to make really good beer, wow.

Nice hazy straw color with a HUGE fluffy white head. Aroma: slightly tart white grape, some fruits, hay, spicy, sweet malts, honey, bretty, banana, flowery, really nice and complex. Just like I want my saisons. Taste is slightly sour, nice bready maltiness, lemon, citruus, ripe fruits, spicy, wheat, maybe some honey, hay, flowers. Once again Hill Farmstead makes an outstanding, refreshing, complex saison! Love it!

From bottle from brewery. Aroma is yeasty, floral, and a little sweet. Pours a hazy golden color with off white head. Tastes very tart with pepper, spice, and some funkiness. Very dry aftertaste. High carbonation. Light body with a dry finish.
Belle corpulence, le miel est vraiment à sa place, légère touche houblonnée. Leffervescence au poil rend lexpérience encore pus agréable.

750ml bottle, split with Ross, graciously gifted by Tim and Dan.  Thanks! Pours a hazy light amber color with a white head and some lacing.  Aroma is yeasty, clove, maybe a little bready malt.  Medium on the palate with soft carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, bready, yeasty, some lemon, some clove, some grass, with a light tart finish.  Very tasty.  Very glad I was able to try this.

Bottle 75 cl. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is excellent. Gooseberries, citrus and brettanomyces notes play up against a more estery farmhouse yeast. A hint of leather, tangerine and flowers, and a small soapy note. Taste is bright and lightly sour. Notes of tangerine, lemon, huge farmhouse characteristic, lovely phenolic and slightly sour yeast profile. Honey provides a bit of smoothness in the finish. A lovely bright and yeast forward slightly sour and funky saison. WIN!

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Somewhat hazy pale golden beer with a rich white head. Floral aroma, sourish, honey notes, dandelions, lemongrass, hay, barnyard notes, perfume, vinous, spicy notes, biscuits, citrus, grapefruit, tart and earthy. Sourish perfume flavor,vinous, sour, barnyard, earthy, grass, dandelions, spicy, lots of grapefruit, pine, citrus, biscuits, raisins, dust, tart, rather bitter, fresh and with loads of flavors. Long bitter sourish finish with dust, earthy notes, regime and grapefruit.

Pours a hazy lemon yellow with a huge bubbly white head that persists forever being constantly fed by a steady stream of carb bubbles and leaving much lace on the sides of the glass. The aroma is citrus, spicy and a bit funky. Light pepper with lemon and grapefruit aromas mixed with a spicy wheat bready character and a solid shot of earthy yeast funk. The flavor is a little sweet with light sugar and honey before we segue into some really nice juicy citrus and tropical fruits. A hint of pepper and spice and a little bit of yeasty funk and a light tart fruitiness provide a really nice contrast. Medium body with a spirited level of carbonation and a sweet bubbly mouthfeel. This is a great saison! I normally wont go for the style, but if this were more available I could see this being my go to warm weather beer.

Tap at Blind Tiger.  Pours hazy grassy yellow with white head.  Nose of citrus, spice, and funk.  Tastes pretty tart, of grass, grapefruit, pineapple, honey, woody, and light pepper.  It bitter and highly carbonated and quite dleicious

Blind Tiger, NY tap 12oz ($8.50): Pours a hazy yellow, with a white head. Aroma is Brett, funk, yeast, grass, and a bit of dirt. Tasty. Taste is ever so slightly sour. There is a good amount of funk. A nice bit of honey sweetness. Loads of grass. Dry finish. Well-proportioned hops. Quite a good saison.

On tap at The Pony. Pours hazy golden yellow with a white head. Aromas of banana, clove, light spices, yeast, and some lemon. Flavors of bready and yeasty malts, some light spices, light fruit, grassy hops with some light bitterness, and just a touch of bitterness. Mouthfeel isbon the soft side. Nice beer and first rate from HF.

Tap at Farmhouse, Burlington, Vt. Hazy blonde topped with a generous white head. Nice flowery aromas backed by tart fruits and a touch of funkyness. Medium body, crispy mouthfeel, light spiciness, flowery, thirst quenching. Lovely saison.

A - pours effervescent golden honey with low white tight bubbled head. S - nice strong saison aromas. Yeasts, Pineapple, grapefruit, honey, grasses, fresh orange juice, cloves, coriander. M - typical dry crispy vibrant mf. Very high carb. Lingering almost medicinal. T - grasses, bitter grapefruit, light pineapple up front. Cloves, honey, bread, and nice  bitterness follow. Lightly sweet. Notes of minerals, astringent, lemon, and flowers, pepper.   O - very good bitter grassy, lightly fruity honey saison. 8

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2013 750ml bottle into a tulip glass. Vintage unknown, but it was picked up from the source in late October.

A - Pours a rather light golden color. Somewhere between clear and hazy with some visible rising carbonation. Super dense and thick bone white head with excellent lacing and long lasting retention. 

S - Coriander spice, pepper, lemons and a floral grassy finish. Sweet and herbal with some faint cheese and earthiness. 

T - Coriander and pepper lead into some lemons, flowers and sweet honey soaked bread. Less earthy than the nose. Dry with a lingering bitterness. Mouth feel is crisp, tart and lively.

O - A very solid and well made saison. The addition of honey is nice and provides a subtle sweetness to balance out the spice and floral aspects.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2014 Bottle (750 ml). Shared by Jean-Michaël, thanks! Hazy yellow  with a medium white head and massive lacing (like almost all HF beers). Aroma is of massive Saison yeast and brettanomyces with a weird presence (some of my tasting buddies thought it was sulfur, other thought it was honey... I don know). Taste is also of brettanomyces and Saison-like. Mouthfeel is acidic and long lasting. Not my  favorite HF Saison, but still a great beer!  8-4-8-4-15 = 3.9

EDIT: Bottle (750 ml). 2014 version. Hazy bright yellow/golden with a huge mostly lasting white head and some lacing. Aroma is really enticing  with brettanomyces, nice wild notes, honey/floral presence, lemony notes and a nice herbal touch. Taste is of brettanomyces, honeyed malt, nice tartness, lemon/citrus, floral/herbal notes, yeast and light sweetness. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Kind of smooth/fluffy mouthfeel. Slightly dry finish. So different than the bottle I had in 2012. More tartness and more complexity. The balance on this one is perfect. Amazing drinkability and super quenching. Im stunned! 9-4-9-4-18 = 4.4
Anna, i miss anne .. . pours a deep amber gold .. . great foam .. really good lacing .. . lots of hay and yeast, with some fresh doughy bread.. . very good beer .. . then for a week, i eat people..

750 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you pandableh! Pours hazy pale golden with a huge frothy and fizzy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving sticky lacing and trace on the glass. Smell is tiny sour, fruity, earthy and funky with crackers, dusty dry soil, leather, hay, barnyard, wood, brett, dried flowers, apricots, mandarin oranges, latex and grape juice. Taste is sour, bitter, slightly fruity sweet and funky with crackers, hay, dry soil, allspice, mandarin oranges, plums, dry wood, dark grapes, grapefruit rinds, coriander, brett and hints of honey. Mouthfeel is crisp, tart, slightly dry and light to medium bodied. Finish is dry, floral and slightly herbal with crackers, dry soil, wood, grape skins, honey, brett, allspice, coriander, white bread, mandarin oranges, lemon balm and plums. Great stuff as usual!

(Bottle) Pours hazy yellow golden with a large white head. The aroma holds crackers, dry whiter bread/baguette, minerals, wet stone, citrus, mild lacto, subtle fruits/esters, light dough, herbs, flowers, spices, latex, touch of wood and bit of earth. Fancy and slim nose. The aroma is dry, light to medium acidic and light bitter with dry, clean and tight malt alongside and hits of herbal and earthy hops. Clear notes of phenols and a whisper of esters. Minerals, spices, flowers and lacto. The mouthfeel is clean, slim and crisp with a light black tea astringent aftertaste. Phenols, citrus and tight malt on the finish. Light bodied.

75 cl bottle @ home
Foams a lot when pouring. Aroma is rather strong on soapy citrus and earthy notes. Palate is too high on CO2. Flavour has earthy notes, soapy citrus and hints of spices. Decent.

750 ml bottle.
Pours a hazy cloudy orange yellow colour with a white foamy head. Aroma of farmhouse, English toffee and some herbal notes. Flavour of sweetish malts, honey, farmhouse, herbs, grassy hops and some floral notes. Some interesting minty pastille notes. Medium bodied, high carbonation and a sweetish, malty, grassy bitter finish with come citrusy tartness. Great stuff.

75 cl bottle.
Pours clear golden color with a large head. Aroma of soap, yeast, citrus fruits, spices and goose berry bush. Flavor of yeast, spics, ripe fruits, herbal notes and apricot. Lots of CO2, sourish palate, dry finish.
2345

750ml bottle from a trade. Thanks pushkinwow!

Pours golden yellow with a massive white head. Aroma of grassy hops, honey, yeast, spices, farmhouse and yeast. Taste is spicy and yeasty with notes of grassy hops and hints of honey. Finish is spicy with hints of honey, grassy hops and yeast. Nice, well balanced and tasty saison.

32 oz growler served in a Portsmouth tulip. Huge thanks to Sean (Sean9689) for hosting the tasting and supplying some rarities.

A: Pours a hazy gold color with with a fluffy white head forming on the pour. It recedes to a a ring and some whisps. Splotchy lace is left down the glass.

S: Yeasty and peppery note are the main attractions of the nose with some green apple and lemon pith.

T: Yeasty and peppery notes from the nose are more prevalent here, but the back bone of lemon rind and pith are more in your face. There is a mildly tart green apple flavor on the finish.

M: Light bodied with nice carbonation. Crisp mouth feel with a drying finish.

O: Very solid overall. I would have liked a little more mustiness, but it was enjoyable and easily drinkable.

Serving type: growler

Reviewed on: 05-14-2012

Poured into a snifter. Big thanks to stevefinny for this. 

4.5 A: Moderately hazed golden yellow color. The bottle gushed a bit on me and I needed two pours to get a full glass. The second pour left almost three fingers of pillowy white head. Retention is very good and tons of lacing is left.

3.5 S: Super dry and super herbal. Thistle, grass, dry hay. Pear leads the fruit party with lemon zest and bitter orange peel. Just the slightest honey component. Some yeasty breadiness.

3.5 T: Quite lemony. Way more than the nose suggested. Tart lemon juice foremost, but also lemon zest - basically lemon merangue pie. Again a big herbal component with the flavors listed in the nose and additionally hints of mint, chard, and parsley. Surprisingly bitter and perhaps a bit too much so. Again the honey is a bit underwhelming, but still a good add. Pear frutiness underneath. 

3.5 M: Lighter body. Good moderate carbonation despite the minor gushing. I like spritzy carbonation in saisons and this only has a touch of that. Still, smooth and decent enough. 

3.5 D: I looked at some reviews after making mine and I must say that either this bottle is different from what others have been drinking or they are imagining smells and flavors. That said, its a good beer, but Id take a HF IPA or porter over this anyday.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-28-2012 02:17:03

Dirty blonde and clear.  The tartness of the wheat in this aroma carries a fiery sensation.  Coriander, clove, lemon, and salt.  Inhaling deeply of all this spice is searingly brisk.  Floral qualities glimmer lightly underneath for some balance, in some earthy hops and the honey presence.

Taut, snappy honey sweetness coupled with the sharpness of the wheat makes for a winningly simple flavor; dusted over with the intricacies of its yeast, it gets more detailed - herbal and weird - as it warms.  Honeyed apples, cinnamon, and banana, together with the beginnings of a pleasant basement mustiness.

Crisp, light to medium palate.  Finishes with a drawn out very tart wheat flavor and lingers; Id like to sit it for a bit, but its put together beautifully and I do believe Ive stated that sentiment verbatim regarding a HF saison in the past.

(Draught) clearish gold, huge frothy eggshell/yellowish head. Nose is floral, grass (like someone cut the fresh grass in this particular area of Vermont), farm and barnyard, very light earthiness. Taste is lightly tart, hint of orange peel, refreshing, bit grassy, so complex its hard to describe, dry and a tiny bit vinous and winey. Reminds of a white wine, and nearly bone dry. Excellent. Just writing the review today, takes me back to 2 months ago. I already miss being at Shauns brewery.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2016 On tap at the Hill Farmstead Farmhouse Ales Festival 2012, VT. Pours cloudy yellow with a sturdy, frothy white head. Gorgeous nose, rife with lemon, fresh hay and barnyard notes. Flavor is delightful, with plenty of lightly tangy citrus, mellow dough, decent sweetness - perhaps a touch more sweetness than some other HF saisons. Medium bodied with smooth, massaging carbonation. Clean, refreshing finish, more tangy lemon and other citrus, very faint funk, hay, a little bit of yeast. Delicious beer. Outstanding.

Beautiful golden yellow color with an incredibly creamy, thick billowing white head. Lacing is thick and sticky. Wow. So far my experience with Hill Farmstead beers is that they are all insanely aesthetically pleasing. Aroma is of hay, barnyard, lemon zest, floral hops. This has a great carbonation level, drinks crisp and goes down very easily. Taste is a nice crisp grainy hay, with some brett barnyard funk, lemon/citrus notes and a mineral earthiness. Very delicious.

Effervescent with a very bright straw yellow color 3 finger head. Hazy and unfiltered.Grassy and has a sweetness from the honey. Citrus fruits are strong in the nose with a bready/yeasty finish. A hint of funk rounds out this beer. The barnyard grassiness is right on the front of the tongue followed by a graprefruity hoppiness that lingers and grabs hold of my mouth and coats ever crevice. Perfect balance and very crisp. The mouthfeel is incredible with the carbonation being high with a medium to low body. A perfect example of this style. Will be sad to see this one go when I drink it all.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2013 Updated for Batch #1 with about a year on it, at this point. Poured a beautiful golden color with a huge two-finger head and great lacing; massive carbonation. Big tangy, bretty, medicinal, band-aid, peppery, lemon peel, floral, honey, herbal, and musty aroma. Taste is  big brett, herbal, sour grain, lemon zest, wheaty, fruity esters, white pepper, funky, grassy, and biscuit with a lightly spicy finish. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation. Very complex with a ton of flavors that meld well together. Lightly sour, spicy, fruity, refreshing and crisp. This one ages beautifully - what a wonderful saison.

Bottle generously shared by colonelforbin.  Thanks Mike.  Pours a slightly hazy golden amber with a big white head that has good retention and leaves a decent amount of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is a funky barnyard earthiness with some honey as well as a light peppery note.  The taste is funky and earthy with a bit of honey flavors, but also quite dry.  The finish is dry with some floral notes and a bit of lingering honey.  Medium body.  Medium-high carbonation.

Bottle: Poured hazy bright straw color ale with a super large foamy head with excellent retention and super good lacing. Aroma of light rustic malt notes with nice floral notes with lightly sweet honey notes. Taste is a good mix between some rustic malt with light hay notes and sweet floral honey notes with light hoppy notes. Body is above average with great carbonation and no apparent alcohol.

hazy dark golden color with lasting frothy white head. bready sour dough, barnyard piss, dry spice, light fruit aromas. Light to medium bodied. Dry hay, sour dough flavors with dry spices, earthy hoppage, light fruitage-- I could drink this shit every night---very fucking good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Draught at the Festival of Farmhouse Ales. Pastel yellow. Nice head. Grassy, citrus nose, a lot of hay. Interesting and subtle. Rather sweet, tangy orange, a little lemon and creamy and bread. Not big time sours but a little bretty. Nice, full, tasty.

On tap at 2012 Hill Farmstead Festival of Farmhouse Ales. Farm field, floral, herbal and crisp aroma. Alluring. The flavors are complex and move well together. Nice clean malt sugar paired with an herbally complex spicy yeast signature. Then a wonderful twist of drying and quenching hops. Light, airy, subtle and detailed. Fantastic! Reminds me the most of a classic example like Dupont.
bottle. Pours gold foamy white head, nose of floral spice honey flavors of sweet honey floral honey. Grainy good saison.

Bottle shared by Andy. Pours hazy gold with a big fluffy white head. Flowery, yeasty, and spicy, comes across very clean and smooth, but with a nice underlying quasi-funky saison yeastiness. Light lemony notes and some light honey sweetness complement. Outrageously drinkable and very enjoyable.

bottle at daks 1/22/12.

hazy yellow with a big white head.

it smells of honey, florals, lemon, straw, pale malt, sweaty and some medicinal notes.

the flavor is the same...rather....

sharp and crisp. 6/4/6/3/14-

Bottle from DLD 12.  Thanks to Kan, I believe, for this pour. Pours a hazy yellow color. Great tart hay aroma some bread and tropical fruits. Earthy bitter grassy flavors that blend well.  Good stuff. 8/4/8/4/16
Bottle. Pours honey yellow. Aroma of funky sour. Taste was little sour and slight sweet

Pours a hazy honey color with a thick creamy white head...excellent retention and lacing.  Aroma has nice bretty barnyard notes and a slightly sweet floral note.  Flavor has great bretty notes...mild funkiness with touches of leather and spice.  Mouthfeel is light/medium and silky with a dry spicy/bretty/leathery finish that lingers nicely.

Bottle shared at MuckFest 3 - Friday evening addition. Pours a richer straw yellow hue, a bit champagney with big cakey brighter white head atop is thick, laces well, sticks around like a beast. Aromas are touches of honey, earthy hops, gentle spice and girthy spice comes into the fold as it warms. Bready malts, touch of crisp honey essence, weeds and florals. Initial is medium bodied offering touches of white grape, florals, and bready malts. Touch of honey, florals, and gentle grass grow. Gentle spice, doughy malts and bread, cereal grains. Growing touch of dryness, spice, and bready hay, straw, grassm gentle kiss of fruit in the middle is fleeting. Really dries out, spices well. Solid offering but not my favorite Saison from HF.

750ml bottle pours a hazy, puply yellow, looks like grapefruit juice.  Nose is herbal, sage, thyme, light lavendar, floral, honey.  Flavor has some light lemon, herbs, lavendar, thyme, sage.  Medium bodied, soft finish.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, thanks Brandon!  Hazy golden with fluffy white head, aroma brought notes of biscuit, bread, caramel, white grape, pear and peach notes, some yeasty notes with a hint of earth, pepper and more spice, nice.  Taste is nice as well with spicy yeast, pepper phenols, so-me hints of fruit, biscuit, bread, earth, the peach and pear notes come through again with slight funky notes, finishing fairly dry and refreshing.  Another good one from them.

Bottle. Pours a hazy straw yellow color with a creamy white head. Good head retention. Aroma of bready malts, spice, tropical fruits. The taste is tropical fruits, bread, caramel. Medium bodied. Nice beer.

750mL courtesy of Mike, A saison at this big bad BA BW tasting of sorts, and this one rocked.. the farmhouse takes a back seat to me here with the well carbonated lemon pepper beer.. really quite awesome.

First of all, huge thanks to MaxxDaddy for this bottle - you are far too generous, Max - hazy gold pour, with a frothy, lasting lace -  aroma is a wonderful mix of lemon zest, pineapple, sage, wildflower, basil - medium soft carbonation in the mouth - flavor is drier than expected - the honey is present in the finish, but the approach is a little tart, followed by earthy bitterness, moderate funkiness - light flinty mineral notes - finish has some lavender and other dry herbal notes - I love this beer.

Bottle @ Matts house, courtesy of notalush. Brandon, you are neato. Milky yellow golden appearance with a white head. Super floral, light honey, somewhat spicy, herbal, somewhat citrusy aroma. Quite tangy, rich bretty, orange citrusy, somewhat herbal, rich estery flavor. Quite nice Saison.

Bottle from joeybones3.  Thanks, man.  I got a very small taste of this at the last Hunahpu release (thanks to whoever that was) so I knew it would be good but man is this beer special.  It pours a golden color with a big lasting fluffy white head that leaves some substantial lacing.  A wonderful array of scents invade the aroma consisting of citrus peel, grass, leafy hops, spring flowers, soft herbal notes, and raw honey.  Wow.  The flavors are so incredibly well integrated.  Theres a crackery-honey sweetness to this but its super dry in teh finish with a touch of fresh citrus bitterness.  Straw, grass, and herbal notes mix in well with plenty of rustic farmhouse character.  What an amazing beer.  One of the best Ive had.

Brought in to Chucks by a customer. Pours light and hazy like pulpy lemonade with minimal head. Smell is funky honey, lightly tart. Sweet, tart, barnyard all rolled in to one. Really good, glad to have tried it.

Bottle, courtesy Mike. Thanks! Pour is cloudy straw gold, small fizzy white head, good retention/lace. Aroma is tart, fruity esters, citrus, pineapple. Taste is bone dry, lemon, pepper, cracker malts, citrus hops. Palate is dry, high carbonation, bitter finish. Good

Bottle to oversized snifter (thanks Nate).  Looks good; light-orange with ample head and carbonation.  Smells pretty good too; honey and yeast.  Tastes good; a very nice saison.  Nice on the palate too.  This is a great example of the style!

750 mL bottle. Batch 2. Poured into a tulip.

Pours a chilled golden lemon color with a frothy white head. Thick clumps of lacing and never ending retention. Smells like a slightly sweet, funky barnyard. Dominated by pepper, clove, and lemongrass and backed up by a surprising punch of candy like honey. Medium bodied, soft and delicate on the palate, but doesnt finish as crisp or dry as expected for the style. Flavor is very similar to the other non-BA HF saisons and has a traditional earthy, musty and funky finish. Strong grass, biscuit malt and earthy flavors complement a surprisingly noticeable amount of honey. Another solid saison from HF, with a subtle, enjoyable twist.

750 ml bottle obtained from the Farmstead. A light honey colored brew with a gorgeous frothy white head. Aroma of spice and honey malts. Great yeast profile. Very clean drinking, not sticky or too sweet. Very well balanced hoppiness. Bravo Hills!

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2013 Pour from a growler that someone handed to lushawn at DLD12. Pours a hazy yellow color with a moderately sized white head. Notes of honey, bread, pepper, and faint lemon citrus. Bright and dry. Light body, medium carbonation. Solid saison but not up to the level of the other HF ones Ive had. Re-Rate: The new batch is remarkably better than the first one. Looks the same, but brings more honey and citrus in perfect harmony. Sweet, tart, dry, and refreshing. So nice.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2013 750ml... Pours a hazy yellow light copper color with a 1 finger head that laces out nicely.  Aromas of honey wheat, malt, green hay with a touch of pepper, citrus and sourdough.  Its flavors roll along with the initial round maltiness which instantly gets lifted by zesty citrus peel grassy freshness. From there it rounds out again with some bitter hop flavors, alot of funky earth notes... really a nice finish!

On tap at the brewery in Greensboro, VT. Pours a cloudy, yellow-orange colored body with an inch thick, dense and frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is a nice mix of spicy hops and lightly sweetened malts. Some pale cereal malts with a touch of honey sweetness, grass, hay, grapefruit citrus, florals, pepper, and a bit of a lemon zest. Flavor is similar. Smooth cereal pale malts up front with a light honey sweetness. Zesty grapefruit citruses with a touch of lemon, some white pepper, hay, grass, and soft florals. This finishes dry and a bit spicy and grassy, but the cereal malts keep it smooth and add a touch of honey sweetness. Light bitterness following a very smooth and soft, medium-light body and a gentle, moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid saison. I wasnt as impressed with this as some of the other raters, but it was still fairly complex and well done. Good beer.

750 ml bottle. A lightly hazy medium blonde beer, with a huge, fizzy, frothy, lacing almost fully lasting white head. The aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted bread), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs, lemon), lightly to moderately yeasty (earth, dough), with notes of honey, exotic fruits, pepper, spicy/perfumey herbs/flowers (hardly definable, but like lavender/basil/dandelion), oranges. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, dry and very long finish with moderate bitterness. This is a hell of a beer... Noble and American hops are amazingly integrated, live everything in this stuff, including the honey presence, subtle but effective. Marvellous from the beginning to the end, a true showstopper and shared with my mother Anna. I m hugely impressed by Hill Farmstead and I definately need more.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Hazy golden, straw yellow.  Nice, massive fluffy white head, great lacing clinging all around the glass.  Dense skim remains on top after each sip.  The nose is full of lemon, grain, green apples, hay, oranges, mild coriander,  light funk and just a hint of sweet honey.  Reminds me a bit of the beautiful nose of cuvee de castleton.  Taste follows suit with a nice grainy base complemented by a blend of mellow, fresh fruits (lemon, apples, oranges, grapes).  Mouthfeel is very nice with a light to medium body, assertive carbonation keeps things moving, crisp refreshing finish.  Overall a very nice saison that hangs with the best.

750ml bottle, enjoyed by my lonesome on the balcony overlooking Sunny Isles Beach with a delicious prosciutto/chorizo/pecorino sandwich on hours-fresh sourdough. This is the life.The body is a slightly hazy, gorgeous golden shade that shines brightly in the sun, revealing continuous streams of champagne-like bubbles. The effervescence feeds a creamy, steadfast blanket of tight-bubbled, snow-white foam. Short, fat, curled flares of lace harken to the profile shot of a chunky ocean wave. Beautiful beer.The aroma on this beauty suggests of the very sourdough bread that I enjoy along side it.  Fresh, lightly malted cereal grain and softly sweet dough provide a subdued backdrop, while masterfully subtle, peppery wildflower notes and aged, grassy hops come across dry, dusty, and mouthwatering. Honey is nearly fully attenuated, and was clearly used with (welcomed) restraint. The yeast is distinct, offering a soft pungency that I enjoy.Flavors largely follow the nose. Fresh, bready grains are kissed with the softest possible glaze of honey. I get a distinct hint of flaked oats, and maybe some hay. Zippy, dusty, peppery spice nods to marigold, dandelion, and other such dry, fragrant wildflowers. Hops are again grassy, providing the perfect amount of bitterness.  So tasty.The palate approaches perfection. The moderately substantive body has been attenuated to the point where I dont think an additional micron of alcohol could be squeezed out of this thing. Dry as a bone, this beaut is laced with intense, lively carbonation that intensifies the wildflower spiciness before cleaning the palate off entirely. Even after the swallow, I can still feel tiny bubbles tickling the roof of my mouth.If I close my eyes, thoughts of Saison Dupont rush in...only this is better. Yes, I realize that is a bold statement. Its spicier (without going overboard), drier, more flavorful, and perhaps most importantly, more ambitious without getting carried away. Excellent beer from arguably the best saison brewer in the country at the moment.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2016 Pours a hazy glowing yellow color with small head and lacing. Aromas of earthy funk, lemon, brett, and some carmelized sugar sweetness. Very crisp and drinakble. Only a little bit tart in finish. Excellent. Re tried a few times, beautiful tropical funk and salty earth with some belgian tones. Another great brew from HF. A top notch staple in all regards.

750 ml bottle via my my main man Derek; clear dark gold with thick, eggy white head; dry lemon, white sugar, light grain, honey and creamy wheat; ymmm, drinks with a delicate sweetness and creamy wheat; soft, creamy mouthfeel with dry honey, stale hay, fizzy, lively mouthfeel with sweet malt, honey and lemon; wow, perhaps not as dry as one would like in a saison, but the honey gives it a sweetness and depth and really works with the added mouthfeel; this one is yum and one of the best saisons Ive had in a long while

Anna (2/23) 2nd bottle (and from the newest batch) - not quite blown away and his doesnt pop flavor wise; smooth, dry honey with stale hay, dry malt; some minor bitterness and astringency that I dont remember from before; new yeast this batch I think I read? more bland and watery this time around; some yeast profile but not as complex as before

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours clear honey yellow with a nice fluffy white head. Dry, peppery yeast on the nose with a bit of acetone and some fruity sweetness. Taste is more of the same, has a nice dry, fruity maltiness with a dusty yeast and some light floral hopping. Has that same acetone note with some real bitter grassy hoppiness that lasts through the finish. Big fluffy body with ample carbonation. The hop profile ruins it for me--just too sharp and bitter. Not my cup of tea.
Straw color with white head. Grassy with a little bit of honey. Taste follows. Very good beer
Pours a hazy yellow with white head.  Nice carbonation.  Aroma has honey, spice, and yeastiness.  Taste is semi-sweet with some light peppery notes. Medium bodied and a dry finish.  Pretty good.

Pour from a bottle thanks to a generous friend. Light golden yellow in color. Pure white head. Aromas are fresh with flowery notes and earthy yeast. Light to medium on the palate and very smooth. The initial flavors are of lemon, herbs, and natural honey. Just when you think the honey is going to make this beer a tad sweet it nicely dries out and finishes really balanced. Long finish in a complex way for a saison. Excellent beer.

750ml bottle. Clear straw yellow with a creamy white head. Wheat, spice, lemon, belgian yeast, some honey. High carbonation, moderate body, relatively light and fresh, mild sweet, becomes dry, some spice on the end. Tasty but quite mild.
Bottle, pours a bright yellow, good head, very floral and a nice sweet body, the honey really comes through. Really solid stuff

Courtesy of BOLTZ7555. Pours clear pale gold with near white head. The aroma is smooth with honey sweetened spicy yeast and hints of meadow ripened light skinned fruits. The taste is similar but rather than the smoothness noted in the nose the fairly high degree of carbonation creates a sort of prickly punctuated array of flavors mostly consisting of various saison like yeasty spices as well as a mix of slight tartness and a sense of apple and pear like fruitiness. Into the finish it gets a bit pepper too.
22 ounce bottle poured a hazy yellow pour, aromas of creamy honey, yeast, lemon, some spice and a touch of hops.  Tatses of honey forward, yeast, peppery lemon zest and more honey.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2012 Purchased at Hunger Mountain Co-Op in Montpelier, VT in early December. Its the first HFS beer Ive picked up and the first that Ive opened. Poured at 45 Degrees F into a red wine glass.

A - Soft and really beautiful pour. The head was larger than I thought at about 3 fingers with ultra tiny, almost creamy bubbles. The beer itself is golden with a nice haze and tons of bottom to top bubbles.

S - Tons of delicious farm style / light belgian yeast is what I get first of all. TONS of vermont honey which I have daily at breakfast so I know what Im talking about. Mild banana and some cheese aspects.

T - Its a pretty bready beer with only mild honey notes. Its a very dry beer...maybe champagne yeast? I dont really know but it smelled far better than it tasted.

M - Tons of carbonation, light bodied and very easy to drink. The lingering yeast taste is over the top for me.

O - Its a very tasty beer but its a bit more funky and more bready than I wished. I wouldnt buy it again but HFS is local to me so Ill probably try more of their beers soon.


UPDATE: I had a 2010 Anna on Tap last night. Huge difference and showed me what this beer does over time. The carbonation mellows, the beer becomes smoother and honey is far more pronounced.
750 thanks to Glouglouburp. Not a dry saison. Taste of honey. Slight taste of brett or that nice saison funk that is just there in the background. Wheat. Really nicely done.

Hill Farmstead never ceases to amaze me.  They now make my 3 top saisons and have many more to try.  This is so nicely sweet and spicy with crisp citrusy hop finish.  Could easily drink a 750 and want more.

Expected so much more from this one...aroma of grapefruit, pepper, yeast, and dust.  Flavor is also that of a sandstorm accompanied by citrus, spice, and a hint of honey.  The honey was secondary and didnt play a primary role.  Good but not great.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2015 Thanks to my ex-girlfriend dating a vermont guy and bringing this bottle back. Im a sucker for honey. This saison strain is refreshingly clean. The honey is deliciously amazing.
Cloudy gold pour, nice white head.  Honey forward aroma, some yeast and floral notes.  Flavor is yeasty, honey, creamy, not bad.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 Thanks to MtGoat.  Pours a radiant golden orange, decent head with creamy retention, lively bubbles.  Fresh aroma of pear, floral lemon, yeast, light straw.  Taste carries pale malts, white pepper, herbal hop bitterness, mild honey sweetness and clean dry brett finish, little aftertaste.  Light, in the mouth with prickling carbonation.  Overall a great, well-balanced saison, but lacking in complexity for me compared to other Hill Farmstead brews of the same style.

25.4 oz bottle.  Hazy yellow straw with brief white froth.  Nose is honey, dough, lemon and grain.  Medium light with a tingle.  Taste is bitter lemon and herbs with a touch of sweetness.  Lovely, subtle, clean saison.
750 ml. Bottle pour.  Golden yellow color with a nice white head.  Honey, hops, and a little sweetness.  Very refreshing.

Bottle Cloudy straw-colored ale with a small, creamy, white head. Great retention. The bouquet is a fruity, spicy mélange of lemon peel, lavender, a mild clove phenol and an interesting blend of standard spice-rack fixtures that I cant quite isolate. Light to medium-bodied and very effervescent. The flavor is mainly of pale malt sweetness and herbs, although there is a restrained element of acidity. Finishes crisp, sweet and moderately tangy. Bottle courtesy of landhoney!

1st October 2011Bottle shared at the Kernel Brewery. Thanks to tendermorsel for sharing - Cheers Mike! Hazy gold beer, little white head. Dry softish palate. Okay malt - slight sweetness from the honey. Mild mild citrus. Mild seltzer minerals. Dry finish. Inoffensive and drinkable if a bit drab.

Bottle at Kernel Brewery tasting. It pours hazy light orange, with a foamy white head. The nose is honey, grain, farymward, oatmeal and delicate floral. The taste is lemon, honey, floral, grape, hay, straw, farmyard, bread and light spice, with a dry finish. Medium body, fine foamy carbonation and slightly cloying mouth-feel.

A: The beer pours a slightly hazed golden color with a finger or two of white foam.

S: A very estery aroma.  Lots of lemon, lemon zest, and pears to this.  Hints of spices, particularly white pepper, followed by a fair amount of banana and pale, bready malt notes.

T: The flavor features a bit more of the pepper and banana than expected from the nose.  Lots of sweet apple with a hint of lemon zest, spices, and yeast.  Pale malts give the beer a nice light base.

M: Light to medium in body with a high carbonation and dry finish.

O: A really nice saison.  Lots of different flavors going on, all of which are enjoyable.

Courtesy of rayl101
Bottle:  The aroma is high on floral notes along with honey, lemon/lemon peel, and a touch of yeast.  It pours a slightly hazy gold with some sediment and a large white head that fades within a minute or so.  The flavor starts with a quick dose of honey and yeast.  The finish is moderately floral along with some light lemon peel and lemon.  Light-medium bodied with moderate soft carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2012 on tap at brewpub. pale yellow, slight haze, nice head, retention and lacing. aromas of yeast, tobacco and citrus. cereals, pepper, coriander, orange, honey. soft carbonation, medium body, sticky. excellent brew.  re-rate: brett is new here, and upfront, fairly present grassy-citrusy hops for an almost medium long finish. hint of sweetness. still... excellent!

Poured from a 750 ml bottle. batch 2 i think. its labeled at least. Pours a clear golden color with a frothy huge white head. Smell is a bit funky with a honey floral component mixed with bready malt and a touch of grassy hops. taste is clean bready malt with lots of clean saison esters finishing with a lovely honey floral finish. mouthfeel is light and heavily carbonated. No alcohol to feel. Overall a lovely saison.

Thanks to imagineiii for sending this bottle out my way. Served in a Hill Farmstead long-stem tulip.

Pours a moderate honey golden color with a large, creamy white head. Great retention and loads of spotty lacing on the way down. Thin cap throughout. The nose carries some light earth and spice. Mild white pepper in the background as well as a touch of sweet honey. Light wheat and bread notes as well. The flavor is very mildly sweet with a nice malt touch and a bit of light honey flavor. Saison yeast is there as well as slight pepper. Light to medium body and slightly chewy. Very tasty.

Serving type: bottle

750 mL bottle that I purchased from the brewery a few weeks ago.  Pours a hazy opaque gold.  Permanent head on it, looks like a light bed of bubbles.  Very impressive.  Smell is nice and sharp, peppery.  Almost seems to dance on the tongue, and you get hit with the honey in the taste.  Very good.

Bottle, split with mcberko. Pours pale yellow with lots of carbonation and a thick foamy white head. Aroma of yeast, stale lightly sour fruits, funk, citrus and wheat. Flavour is quite yeasty, with light crisp citrus and wheat. Palate is highly carbonated, tingly, medium-bodied. Complex.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2014 750mL bottle, pours a cloudy blonde with a small white head. Aroma is complex and tart, with lovely brett funk, light tartness, and a touch of honey. Flavour is extremely complex, with an amazing mix of tart notes, barnyard funk, lemony zest, and not really any honey sweetness. Phenomenal stuff. A classic Hill Farmstead saison.

Pours a hazy golden yellow color with a two finger frothy white head that has good retention, slowly fading into a lasting ring.  Spotty lacing left behind.  

Slightly earthy, spicy aroma with zesty pepper, coriander, bready yeast and light golden fruit.  Subtle earthy funk from the saison yeast with hitnts of grass and straw.  Sweetness from the honey along with hints of apple and pear.

Medium bodied with lots of earthy, bready yeast  adding fullness to the palate.  Slightly funky but not too much so with hits of grassy hops and straw as well as a lot of crisp, light fruit.  Hints of apple, pear and banaba add to the sweetness of the honey.  Spicy presence with hints of coriander and pepper linger into a dry finish.  Complex, flavorful and refreshing.

Bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a white head that lasts and laces slightly. Aroma has a good amount of honey with some light fruits and flora with a hint of Belgian yeast. Flavor starts with sweet honey and adds some flora and light fruits with a bit of sweet grain as well. A bit sweet but good.
Thank you, yespr. Mild brett aroma. Hazy yellow colour. Small white head. The flavour is nicely bretty with a hint of grapes, perhaps white wine. Nicely dry hop finish.

Bottle. Pale slightly hazy yellow pour with immaculate white head. Aroma of fresh grain, some citrus notes, honey and a touch of yeast. Flavor is soft and subtle, light grainy sweetness, some honey, light yeasty spiciness. Palate: soft carbonation, light and fluffy. Elegant and delicious.

Bottle 750ml. @ yespr blindtasting. [ Bottle #8. ]Unclear medium orange yellow colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, pale malt, grape, light peppery, moderate hoppy, citrus, moderate to light light heavy yeasty, brett, yeast. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet, light acidic and moderate bitter with a long duration, fruity. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110526]
Bottle. Poured a cloudy yellow color with a very large sized white head. Aromas of floral, straw, spices, and fruity. Tastes of straw, spices, citrus, and floral.

Aroma has a lot going on. Hoppy, floral, a bit of herbal qualities with. Flavor has a bit of tang with the hops, sweetness, nice dry finish with a touch of yeast and bread. Finished a touch bitter. Awesome.

Tasted on 5/24/11 from a 750mL capped bottle purchased at Hill Farmstead, thanks to Ryan.  Pours cloudy yellow with a thick white head that slowly recedes to thin spotty lace.  The nose is fruity with spicy saison yeast, along with a lightly bitter herbal component.  The flavor is lightly sweet up front with some honey, hay and cereal malt, a fruity and spicy yeast character, and a lightly bitter herbal flavor as well.  The body is light with lively carbonation and a long bitter honeyed finish.
on tap @Capones RBSG-pours an off white head and cloudy yellow color.  Aroma is tart /vinegar-light/medium fruit.  Taste is tart /vinegar-light/medium fruit.  Semi drying finish.

golden pour, aroma is over ripe pears, honey,perfumey,  floral yeast.  oily mouth feel with some light carbonation.  Flavor is honey, Floral perfume, honeysuckle, tangy grain, yeasty richness, clean and crisp.  Tasty

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2012 Typical saison pour- straw with a massive white head.  Crisp highly attenuated barley, tons of honey, stonefruit, and grassy farminess. Light airy palate with supple effervescence and a dry attenuated finish.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a fluffy large white head.  Aroma of wildflowers, mild honey, yeast, barley and hops.  Taste is much the same as the aroma.

Bottle 75 cl. Blind tasting. Courtesy of yespr. Opaque yellow with a small white head. Citrus and yeast in the nose. Medium body, dry and lightly astringent citrus notes - grapefruit even - with a yeasty touch and quite some yeast. The finish is dry. 260511

Light floral nose with fresh herbs and bright golden fruits. The taste is very dry and lightly tart with light to moderate bitterness,  tastes of pineapple, peach, peat, some cotton candy, peppery yeast and fresh flowers. Fantastic.
75 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange. Funky, fruity and smooth floral. Crisp hoppy and brett. Citrusy, smooth, sweet and crisp bitter. Ends medium dry and smooth.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 hazy gold, thin white head. Honey, strong pineapple Brett, light dust and Earth. Flavor very soft, light yeast and bubblegum, less brett and less sweet. soapy thin body, dry and decently bitter finish.
Bottle at Yespr - Blind Tasting #8. Cloudy yellow - white head. Peppery, fruity, soapy notes, nice bretty notes, wheaty, zesty, bitter flowery, smooth body,  a bit orval like !!!

#8 at yespr blindtasting
clear yellow, smooth white head. very nice yeasty and lovely fruity aroma. flavor is yeasty, bretyy, mild fruit peel. Very nice, i think its a really good saison.

Bottled. Blind no 8 @ Yesprs. Pale yellow coloured. Off white dense head. Aroma of sweetness, yeast,fruits and citrus. Flavour of yeast, grapes, fruits, honey, lemon. Medium bodied. Grapy and citric end.

A hazy golden beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of yeast, pepper and other spices, and lemon. The flavor is sweet with notes of flowers, pepper, lemon peal, and newly cut hay, leading to a tart finish.

Pours a cloudy bright lemon rind yellow with a profuse billowy sticky white head. Awesome nose, lots of pineapple and lemon zest with a nice sweet presence and citrusy character. Nice and zesty dry, light earthy yeast character with mild spicy notes and citrus rind bite. Light effervescent body and lovely finish

750mL thanks to noodleuser. GUSHER! The pour is a hazy gold with a gigantic, Brett induced, pillowy white head. Great retention and massive lace. Nose is fruity, spicy, full on Brett B/L, ginger, lemon/lime, bright citrus and spiced grapefruit. Taste is sharp, Bretty (ginger, hay, straw), wheat, biscuit, still pretty malty. Does well as saison. Palate is dry, spritzy, neutral, cleaned out from the Brett.

750ml bottle shared by noodleuser: Gushed a little upon opening, but eventually poured a clear deep golden bronze with a spotty-lacing white head.  Has a fresh piny hoppy nose with some doughy malts, light bretty funk and yeasty esters.  Starts with a clean semi-sweet biscuity maltiness with good bittering hop balance and some floral complexity before a slightly warming finish.  A smooth and enjoyable saison.

Bottle shared by Noodleuser.  Pours hazy pale yellow with a large, frothy white head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (straw, hay, cookie), average hops (floral, citrus), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of Brettanomyces and farmhouse.  Flavor is heavy malt (straw, hay, cookie), average hops (floral, citrus), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of Brettanomyces and farmhouse.  Medium body and carbonation, low warmth with a dry finish.

Bottle courtesy of noodleuser, thank you sir!  Cloudy golden color, medium white head.  Incredible aroma of lavender and perfume.  Taste is hay, white pepper, and just a touch of sourness.  Dry finish.  Terrific.

75cl (hand?)bottle, thanks Joel.  Gusher, medium white head atop cloudy amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, spicy, straw, some grassy, light bread.  Taste is medium sweet, straw/grassy, some spicy/funk, white pepper.  Light-medium body, light wateriness, acidity.

Bottle.  Cloudy/hazy orange golden with a nice, steady white head.  Nose is dry, zesty, light brett, lemon, a bit of honey sweetness-- oh so sweet on the nostrils.  Flavor is equally dry, some light brett, zest, spice, phenols.  Carbonation may be a tad high, but Id rather err on that side, especially in this style.   Really tasty and ultra refreshing.  Yummers.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 750 ml Bottle Shared by Egadjzis.  I have had on tap, and the bottle seems a bit more conditioned and complex than the tap.  Pours a nice deep hazed golden with a lively big rocky white head- and good lacing.  Aroma is more powerful due to the lively high carbonation in the bottle- sea foam, slight grapefruit zest, lemon hint, earthy light farmhouse funk mixed with a white grapeskin- kind of a txakoli wine aroma- herbal grassy, slight pear and melon fruits- mixed with slight tropical fruits, earth, then slate/mineral.  Flavor is light bread, cracker, toast, almost fruit juicy and wine-like, subdued tropical notes, light brett funk, earth then more mineral slightly tart wine with some herbal hints as the fruits fade.  Dry crisp finish yet still complex in the aftertaste.  Easy drinking and very unique.  Nice Biere de Miel/Saison!

Tap @ RnH.  The aroma is yeasty, pepper, fruity.  The flavor is the same, with a component of earthiness.  The appearance is is hazy yellow, white head.  The finish is pepper, fruit.  Medium/thin in body.   Decent and enjoyable.

On tap at Rattle N Hum.  Pours a hazed gold with a medium sized white head.  Lightly fuzzy phenolics, wheat and toast.  Sweet cool and crisp.  Wheat, with honey tones.  Light honey and wheat, toast, crisp finish.  Didnt blow me away, but I had it after Flora, so it had an uphill battle ahead of it.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2016 Draft at rnh with the Dan Suarez, Pat and Andrew. Pours a hazy orange body with no head, no lacing. Aroma is dry and sweet honey. Mouthfeel is dryer than Flora with notes of dry alcohol, honey, and nice sweet spice. RETRY::: Sampled several times over the past few years. Anna, to me, embodies the perfect saison when it hits full stride. The mouthfeel is absolute perfection with an effervescent tartness, soft minerality with notes of sweet florals, soft fruits, wine barrel, oak and delicate funky yeast. +0.2

5 oz flight sample. Pours a clear, shimmering yellow straw with a modest, white head that recedes placidly and leaves a spotty surface. Aroma of honey, lavender, nectarines, peaches, and grassy pine dry hops. Medium body with a slick, juicy palate. Flavors or honey and sweet caramel sugars interplay in the flavor and end with an earthy pine resinsy kick. Cool brew.

The drier older brother of flora.  Tastes like the flora without the wine or as much zest... An added banana flavor.  Very colorful and bright flower nectar tang.  A great brew but not as balanced or perfected as flora.
Tap @ rnh. Light hazy yellow color. Nice lacing on side of glass. Tastes lemony and smells wheaty. Really nice and easy drinking. One of the beytter saisons out there

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2011 Bottle provided by Chris, poured into my Hill Farmstead glass... Pours a nice golden honey with an orange tint. Nice carbonation with a bright white head. Great cap and lacing, looks great... The aroma is awesome! On the front its very sweet with lots of fresh oranges, then the finish adds wonderful balance with great floral notes... The taste is pretty good not as good as the nose, but totally crushable. The sweet oranges are mostly gone, so you get a musky floralness from start to finish. Some herbal and banana notes add balance...Mouthfeel is pretty good, very dry, nice herbal finish on the palate...Crushable.

A very solid saison, recommend.

A hazed yellow saison with a thick frothy white head. In aroma, a superb milkey Brett, field flowers, perfumey and smooth. In mouth, a nice cheesey malt, talcum, smooth berries, quite nice. Tasted March 12 2011 with Montreal crew.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2011 750ml bottle opened on March 19, 2011.

Pours a bright and clear icterine, with a massive three finger head. Exceptional clarity on the first pour.

The nose bursts with bright floral attributes, accompanied by sweet honey, orange, and tangerine. Hay-like sweet grains and very light, barely dirty barn notes.

Where the nose is illuminated, the taste is soft and finessed. Honey and floral on the front of the tongue, with a nice citrus and grapefruit component mid-palate, that carries on through the dried-out finish. The early-to-mid palate is like a spring day: warm, with a clean cereal grain anonymity. A combination of sugar sweetness and mineral bitterness, like that in the coating of baby aspirin, shows in the finish, though it doesnt distract too much. Theres some lingering grassy/herbal bitterness on the finish.

Just under medium carbonation, Anna is very full and creamy. The finish is appropriately dry and the final concoction of lemon, grass, and herb lingers in the throat.

Quite enjoyable. One of the two best saisons Ive had in recent memory; this one is just so bright in the nose and raw, yet strangely finessed, in the mouth. I wish it popped as much in the taste as in the nose, but its hard to argue with qua bière de miel.

Bouteille de 750 ml, lors dune dégustation. Arômes de houblon floral et de levure rustique rappelant le pain frais. Robe blonde et légèrement trouble, belle mousse et effervescence assez active. En bouche, la bière montre une très belle texture veloutée et une personnalité très florale. La levure apporte des notes de foin sec et de pain frais. Les céréales sont particulièrement croustillantes. Finale très sèche et présentant une amertume délicate. Très bon et rafraîchissant !

Bottled sample via oakbluff, shared with oakbluff and Savvy1982. Gold in colour with fairly strong carbonation. Aromas are of earhty/herbal hops, lemon peel, sweet grasses, creamy pilsner malts and high quality soap. Equally as complex in the mouth with more soap, lavender, key line, black pepper, and pale malts. Extremely refreshing and is both light and savory on the palate. Yet another outstanding beer from Hill Farmstead.

Draft.  Pours a hazy golden body with a white head and sticky lacing.  Aromatically sweet tart fruit tones of apricots and oranges. A bit of earth, herbs, and pepper tones.  A hint floral with a touch of honey with a fairly drying finish.  Nice.

Bouteille de 750 ml achetée directement à la brasserie. Arôme: Odeur dagrumes et dherbes. Apparence: La couleur est blonde légèrement voilée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun large col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes et dherbes avec une piointe de miel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement astringente. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement sec. (Rating #3550)

Bottle, with MASSIVE thanks to oakbluff. Thanks Scott! Pours hazy gold, with an orange flash; Thick, persistent white head, spotty lacing. Nose is spicy tart oranges, very earthy hops, nice white pepper notes here as well. Flavours of earthy, spicy hops, moderately juicy character, but finishes bone dry. Some almost-funk in the mouth. Cheese?

Pours a clear golden color with a thick white head. The aroma is very appealing, theres herbal hops, wildflower honey, yeast and a mild fruity presence. The flavor is also no slouch, theres a superb balance between the herbal hops, the honey and the yeast, theres again a mild fruity thing going in there. The body is medium with a creamy texture and medium to lively carbonation. This is amazing, Shaun Hill really knows how to brew a great saison.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2011 750ml bottle from HF.
Appearance : Almost clear pale yellow with big foamy white head. Lots of lacing.

Aroma : Nice saison yeast, light rustic. Quite herbal. Light fruits. Nice hops. Great malt. Very fresh nose.

Taste : Nice yeast with herbal hops. Slightly rustic with hops. Finish slightly bitter with yeast and light hay. 

Overall : Honey is not very apparent. I can find it if I look for it but thats all. Nice mouthfeel. Nice fruits on finish with great yeast and hops. Very well balanced and very drinkable. A rather typical saison but so well made. Awesome nose. 

750ml bottle from HF.
Appearance : Almost clear pale yellow medium foamy and creamy white head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Citrusy and yeasty with barnyard notes (brett-ish). Nice herbal and floral hops. Very citrusy and fresh. Malt too.

Taste : Malty and yeasty with light spices. Finish quite dry with light notes of honey. Barnyard notes. Finish quite citrusy too.

Overall : Very drinkable and refreshing. Awesome aroma thanks to the noble hops and the yeast. A little bit too rustic/barnyard especially on taste. Finish is also a little bit too spicy for my taste. Nice carbonation, a bit lively but not too intense. Another solid brew by Shaun. 11/02/18 9,3,7,3,17; 3.9

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2017 My Bottom Line:
Herbal, spicy hops surf this Saisons citrusy waves, while lightly honeyed cereals and haystacks effortlessly leave way for a bitter, wooden undertow and increasing dryness.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-Towering foam attains perfect retention and lacing atop the hazy blond.
-Natural carbonation is fluffy and amazingly soft.
-The finish is the meeting of herbal hops and doughy yeast.
-White grapefruit and citrusy thyme allusions are found throughout.
-The wildflower honey character is more prominent than the flavor profile. It is intelligently integrated.
-At this point, I get the impression that any Saison from Hill Farmstead will be a masterpiece. I dont think I can decide on a favorite since theyre all so complex, authentic and amazingly drinkable.
-Addendum: an 18-month old bottle was absolutely mindblowing. Pretty much perfect, as a matter of fact. Tartness had slowly developed, fitting in perfectly with the rest of the complex and comfortable flavor profile. Wow.
